awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Mechanisms of RNA-directed activation of a Cas9 nuclease competent for DNA interrogation
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will investigate how a complex of an RNA and protein, named CRISPR-Cas9, works as a molecular scissor to change an organism's DNA. CRISPR-Cas9 is natively used by lower organisms such as bacteria to defend against viral infections. The CRISPR-Cas9 system is being adapted as a powerful tool for manipulating genomes of many organisms in a 'by-design and on-demand' fashion. On the horizon are innovations that use CRISPR-Cas9 to produce drought-resistant crops; to combat mosquito transmitted diseases such as malaria; and to cure human illness by fixing an individual's faulty DNA. While studies on CRISPR-Cas9 have advanced rapidly and are poised to revolutionize many fields in biology, details on its mechanism of action remain to be elucidated. This project will fill this knowledge gap by identifying the mechanisms by which RNA molecules convert Cas9's molecular structure into a form suitable for selecting DNA targets. Beyond advancing scientific understanding and methodologies, the project will explore collaborations with biotech companies that may yield new technological applications and promote economic developments. It also includes research training for students at all levels and curriculum innovations such as 'virtual reality' (VR) demonstrations of the Cas9-RNA complex, thus contributing to the development of STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics) workforce.

The overall objective of the project is to elucidate the roles of specific domains of Cas9 and guide RNA in initiating and directing a cascade of conformational changes towards the state ready for DNA interrogation. The proposed work will leverage on the expertise of the PI in the functional and structural (X-ray crystallography) characterization of protein-nucleic acid complexes; and that of the Co-PI in site directed spin labeling studies of nucleic acids and protein-nucleic acid complexes. Experiments will focus on Streptococcus pyogenes Cas9, the workhorse in genome engineering, and test an overarching hypothesis that the interactions of the bridge-helix of Cas9 with specific RNA elements, initiate and induce Cas9 domain rearrangements to assemble a DNA-interrogative protein-RNA complex. Specific Aims are: Dissect the role of the bridge helix in initiating conformational changes in Cas9 (Aim 1); Identify the protein and RNA elements that displaces the nuclease lobe (Aim 2) and a helical domain (HD-III, Aim 3) in response to the bridge-helix conformational change. The results from the three aims will identify the sequential steps in the conformational cascade and will be widely applicable to similar CRISPR-Cas systems.

por.por_cntn:
Cas9 is a protein that helps bacteria protect themselves from viral infections. To do this, Cas9 binds to guide-RNA (gRNA), a type of RNA that guides Cas9 to the invading viral DNA. The viral DNA, present amongst a pool of bacterial DNA, is selectively located based on complementary base pairing between a short region of the gRNA (called the guide) and the DNA. The Cas9 then cuts the viral DNA, which inactivates the viral infection. The simplicity of the mechanism of RNA-guided DNA targeting and cutting by Cas9 has revolutionized its use in gene editing applications.

Cas9 undergoes large structural changes after binding to the gRNA and these changes are essential for Cas9's activity. The purpose of our project was to understand these structural changes and modify them to eliminate non-specific cutting of DNA where DNA with only partial complementarity with the guide region of the gRNA is cut by Cas9. We hypothesized that bridge helix, a helix that is highly conserved in Cas9s from diverse bacteria, is important in organizing these structural changes. Our hypothesis was based on our analysis of the structures of Cas9 in its free and gRNA-bound forms. The structural comparison showed that a sub-region of the bridge helix changes from a loop to a helical form after binding to the gRNA. Through the NSF project, we confirmed the importance of the loop-to-helical transition by substituting two native amino acids within the loop of the bridge helix with the amino acid proline. Proline introduces a kink in a helix and is not favorable in maintaining the helical structure of a protein. We introduced proline substitutions in Cas9 from the bacterium Streptococcus pyogenes, creating a variant called SpyCas9-2Pro. Experimental characterization of SpyCas9-2Pro showed that it cuts on-target DNA (i.e., when there is complete complementarity between the guide region of the gRNA and the DNA) with a high efficiency. SpyCas9-2Pro cuts DNA containing mismatches (i.e., when there is only partial complementarity between the guide region of the gRNA and the DNA) with a lower efficiency than the native SpyCas9. This establishes that impairing the loop-to-helical transition of SpyCas9-2Pro in response to binding to gRNA removes non-specific cutting of DNA, thus improving the stringency of Cas9's activity. We also established that proline substitutions in the bridge helix of Cas12a from the bacterium Francisella novicida reduces the protein variant's ability to cut DNA possessing mismatches with the gRNA. Cas12a is a Cas protein belonging to a different CRISPR system than the Cas9. These results establish that bridge helix modifications can be used as a mechanism to improve the stringency with which Cas9/Cas12a cuts DNA when there are mismatches between the gRNA and the DNA. A higher stringency while cutting DNA is critical in improving the safety of Cas-based genome applications. Since Cas proteins are used widely for gene editing and other biotechnology applications, bridge helix modification will serve as an efficient platform to create a repertoire of highly accurate protein variants. Ongoing studies are aimed at understanding the molecular mechanisms by which the bridge helix modifications provide differential efficiencies while cutting DNA with mismatches and its relation to the position of the gRNA-DNA mismatch.

The NSF project provided diverse societal benefits. The project enabled training of students (high school, undergraduate, and graduate) and postdoctoral trainees in CRISPR-Cas research focused on interdisciplinary approaches. Previous members of the PI's laboratory have contributed to the STEM workforce in academia and industry. PI has integrated CRISPR research into her graduate and undergraduate courses and has emphasized on active learning to convey protein structure-function relation to her students. The bridge helix variants of Cas9 and Cas12a proteins improve the safety of CRISPR-based biotechnology and genome tools. The NSF-funded project has created patented technologies, which will be pursued for industrial collaborations.
